==External links== {{commons category|Jaywalking}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6251431.stm What every Brit should know about jaywalking]; [[BBC News]] * [http://www.theatlanticcities.com/commute/2012/04/invention-jaywalking/1837/ The Invention of Jaywalking]
[[Category:Road transport]] [[Category:Pedestrian safety]] [[Category:Walking]] [[Category:Crimes]]

'''Jeepspeed''' is an [[off-road]] organization and class of racing vehicle. The Jeepspeed organization was founded by Clive Skilton in 2001 after a visit to the [[Dakar Rally]] in Africa with his son and multi-time Dakar Rally competitor, Darren Skilton,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YXow9otLiI8C&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=jeepspeed+clive+skilton&source=bl&ots=J6zz2mwHlC&sig=zx9KsQm5wWsO5S7XR6XN_0PsdMo&hl=en&ei=pQL7TI-BI4-asAObhLT3DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&sqi=2&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=jeepspeed%20clive%20skilton&f=false |title=The Joy of Jeep |page=129 |website=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-14}}</ref> with the intent to build a racing vehicle and series around the affordable and durable [[Jeep]]. Jeepspeed developed relationships with race promoters like MORE and [[Best in the Desert]] to create a five to seven race Jeepspeed racing series each season.<ref name="DirtNewz2008Schedule">{{cite web|title=Jeepspeed Adds Additional Race to their Best In The Desert Race Schedule for 2008|url=http://www.dirtnewz.com/dr-pressreleases/11-2007/bitd-11-28-07.shtml|publisher=DirtNewz.com|accessdate=7 December 2010}}</ref> The class has since expanded into four divisions and opened up to other Jeep and Dodge vehicles <ref name="Jeepspeed Adds to the Fold">{{cite web|url=https://www.jeepspeed.com/racing/how-to-race-jeepspeed#step-1-choose-your-class|title=Jeep Speed How To Race|author=|first=|date=|website=Jeepspeed.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref>.
== Jeepspeed divisions == *'''Jeepspeed Challenge - Stock Class 1700''' - Production Class - is for short wheel base Jeeps with 6 Cylinder and 4 cylinder engines produced since 1984, excluding Pentastar DOHC engines and 2018 Wranglers which must run Jeepspeed Class 2700. Wheel suspension travel limited to 10" front and 12" rear. Maximum width 75.5" measured at outside of tires at widest point. Max tire diameter 33".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jeepspeed.com/images/Documents/Rules/2018/2018-Jeepspeed-Challenge-Class-1700-Rules.pdf|title=2018 Jeepspeed Challenge. Stock Class 1700 Rules.|last=|first=|date=1 January 2018|website=Jeepspeed.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. Dirtnewz.com described it was the largest grassroots racing class in America in 2008.<ref name="DirtNewz2008Schedule" /> *'''''Jeepspeed Cup - Intermediate Class''' 2700 -'<nowiki/>'' is for Jeep and Dodge vehicles that maintain the original appearance and profile. The original bulkhead must be retained together with the original cab floor from bulkhead to rear of driver and passenger seat. Hoods and fenders may be of any material but original appearing radiator grill must be retained. Wheel suspension travel limited to 12" front and 14" rear. Maximum width 87" measured at outside of tires at widest point. Max tire diameter 35" <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jeepspeed.com/images/Documents/Rules/2018/2018-Jeepspeed-Cup-Intermediate-Class-2700-Rules.pdf|title=Jeepspeed Cup Intermediate Class 2700 Rules|last=|first=|date=1 January 2018|website=Jeepspeed.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> *'''''Jeepspeed Outlaws - Modified Class 3700'''''' - The Jeepspeed Outlaws is an off road racing championship for Jeep or Dodge sport utility vehicles and light trucks that are recognizable as a Jeep or Dodge by brand grill, hood and fenders. Wheel suspension travel limited to 15" front and 24" rear. Maximum width 93" measured at outside of tires at widest point. Max tire diameter 37" <ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.jeepspeed.com/images/Documents/Rules/2018/2018-Jeepspeed-Outlaws-Class-3700-Rules.pdf|title=Jeepspeed Outlaws Class 3700 Rules|last=|first=|date=1 January 2018|website=Jeepspeed.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> *'''Jeepspeed Trophy - Open Class 4700''' - Class 4700 has been devised to introduce tube and custom frame Jeeps into the General Tire Desert Race Series presented by KMC Wheels. Jeepspeed Class 4700 vehicles may be combined with Class 3700 until sufficient entries in this new class. Jeepspeed Trophy Open Class 4700 will be identical to Jeepspeed Outlaws Modified Class 3700 but with following exceptions; Wheel base restricted to 119". Front wheel travel 15" max. Rear wheel travel open.<ref name=":0" />
==Notable Jeepspeed teams== *Barry Thompson *Billy Bunch *Eric Sigwing *Eric Helgeson *The Currie Family <ref name="Off-Road Adventures Magazine March 2007">{{cite web|last=Temple |first=Steve |title=Currie Enterprises Not Resting On Its Rearends |url=http://www.oramagazine.com/pastIssues/0307-issue/index.asp?article=manufactureprofile |publisher=Off-Road Adventures Magazine |accessdate=16 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723174619/http://www.oramagazine.com/pastIssues/0307-issue/index.asp?article=manufactureprofile |archivedate=23 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> *Ray Giffith *Eric Heiden *Tom and Mike Barnett *Chris Nissley *Dust Junkies *Filarski Bros *Bruno Zvirzin *Nissley Racing Team (Chris, Bill & Tom Nissley)
==Notable Jeepspeed builds== * [[Xtreme 4x4]] Television show aired in 2006 season episode 10 titled "Jeepspeed Build" featuring the construction of a Jeepspeed race vehicle. * The "10 Day Jeepspeed" by Jason Lafortune and TMR crew.<ref>{{cite web|author=Drew Hardin |url=http://www.jpmagazine.com/featuredvehicles/154_0701_jeep_cherokee_xj_10_day_jeepspeed/index.html |title=Jeep Cherokee XJ - 10 Day Jeep Speed Racer |publisher=Jp Magazine |date=2006-12-12 |accessdate=2016-02-14}}</ref> * ATK Wrangler built by Jon Krellwitz and campaigned in the 3700 class (and [[SCORE International]] Class 3).<ref>{{cite web|author=Christian Lee |url=http://www.4wdandsportutility.com/features/jeep/0812_4wd_1998_jeep_wrangler_desert_race_car/index.html |title=1998 Jeep Wrangler - Desert Race Vehicles - 4 Wheel Drive & Sport Utility Magazine |website=4wdandsportutility.com |date=2008-12-01 |accessdate=2016-02-14}}</ref> Also a [http://www.jeepspeed.net/smf/index.php?topic=442.0 complete build] up of the vehicle from start to finish can be found on the Jeepspeed website
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.jpmagazine.com/eventcoverage/cherokee_racing/index.html "Race your Cherokee -- Jeepspeed"] by JP Magazine *[http://offroad.automotive.com/116355/0910or-nissley-racing-team-1990-jeep-cherokee-jeepspeed/index.html "The Green Streek"] by Offroad Magazine about Jeepspeed competitor Chris Nissley Jeep XJ *[https://books.google.com/books?id=MfTphZTLBskC&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=Jeepspeed+jp+magazine&source=bl&ots=ODfP3LyBBB&sig=nk-9at3DG0TBDWY8tEmvpYdyOHc&hl=en&ei=xfz6TILHHY72tgP37pX3DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&sqi=2&ved=0CFoQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q&f=false "How to Modify your Jeep Chassis for Offroad"] Pages 38–45 *[http://www.4wdandsportutility.com/news/0110_4wd_jeepspeed_desert_racing_4x_news/index.html 4wdandsportutility.com] *[http://www.jpmagazine.com/eventcoverage/154_0707_2007_jeepspeed_biggest_season_yet/index.html Jpmagazine.com] *[http://www.off-roadweb.com/features/1001or_1992_jeep_cherokee_xj/index.html Off-roadweb.com] *[http://www.off-roadweb.com/features/0910or_nissley_racing_team_1990_jeep_cherokee_jeepspeed/index.html Off-roadweb.com] *[http://www.Jeepspeed.com Jeepspeed.com]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]] archives
revision.text:
'''Jennie Bosschieter''' (1882–1900) is a woman who was raped and murdered in [[Paterson, New Jersey]], on October 19, 1900.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Factory Girl Found Dead. Skull Fractured and the Paterson Police Think She Was Murdered. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1900/10/20/105754862.pdf |quote=[[Paterson, New Jersey]]; October 20, 1900. The body of Jennie Bosschieter was found lying a short distance from the Wagaran bridge, on the Bergen side of the Paterson River at 5:30 o'clock this morning. The discovery was made by two milkmen. The head of the girl rested upon a jagged rock, and there was a fracture of the skull near the base of the brain. |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=October 21, 1900 |accessdate=2007-08-21 | format=PDF}}</ref> She was an early victim of the date rape drug [[chloral hydrate]] which caused her death.
==Early life== Jennie was the daughter of Dina Bosschieter (born 1861) from the [[Netherlands]]. She lived with her parents at 155 East Fifth Street in the [[Riverside, Paterson|Riverside section]], and worked at the Paterson Ribbon Company on Vreeland Avenue. She had an older sister Susan and younger brother, Joseph.
==Murder== She left home on October 18, 1900, at 8:10 pm to go on an errand to the drug store, where she met Walter C. McAlister and William A. Death (pronounced "Deeth"). She had previously dated Death but he married another woman. McAlister, Death and two others drank with her in a private party room in Saal's saloon at the corner of River Street and Bridge Street. Her first drink may have been a [[Manhattan (cocktail)|Manhattan]], then she drank an [[absinthe]] [[wikt:frappe|frappe]], and then she had two glasses of Great Western [[sparkling wine]]. She was given two or three doses of [[chloral hydrate]] in her sparkling wine by McAlister. They took her in a carriage to a secluded area, raped her, and she died from an overdose of the drug. They dumped the body on the ground and her head hit a rock.
Her body was found lying a short distance from the Wagaraw bridge (now known as the Lincoln Ave. Bridge) on the [[Bergen County, New Jersey]] side of the [[Passaic River]] in Columbia Heights section what is now Fair Lawn, between 5:30 and 6:15 am. The discovery was made by Marinus Gary on his way to work. Her head rested on a jagged rock, and there was a fracture of her skull near the base of her brain. The damage to her skull was [[postmortem]]. At the trial the defense attorneys tried to blame her death on the absinthe and not the overdose of chloral hydrate. The jury rejected that the death was from the absinthe and that the murder was premeditated.
==Legacy== There was a possible [[copycat crime]] on March 12, 1901 with Mary Paige drugged, raped and found severely ill. Paige did recover. Three boys were convicted of assault and served brief sentences.
==Attackers== *George J. Kerr, was the son of Hugh Kerr (c. 1840 – 1901) and brother of John F. Kerr, a judge. He was married. He served 11 years and nine days of a 15-year sentence.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=George Kerr Leaves Prison After Eleven Years Punishment. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/02/10/104890916.pdf |quote=After having served eleven years and nine days of a 15-year sentence for his part in the murder of Jennie Bosschieter of Paterson, George J. Kerr was discharged from State prison at midnight to-night. His companions, Andrew J. Campbell, William A. Death, and Walter McAllister, will not finish their time until 1921. |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=February 10, 1912 |accessdate=2007-08-21 | format=PDF}}</ref> *Walter C. McAlister, put the [[chloral hydrate]] in her drink *Andrew J. Campbell (born 1875). He served 15 years of his 30-year sentence.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Andrew Campbell Paroled After 15 Years in Jail. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1913/04/17/100394669.pdf |quote= |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=April 17, 1913 |accessdate=2007-08-21 | format=PDF}}</ref> *William A. Death, served in the [[Spanish–American War]] and was married
==Others== *Marinus Gary, who found the body, worked for Alyea Brothers feed mill *Augustus Sculthorp, the carriage driver *Vroom, the coroner *Graul, chief of police *Christopher Saal, owner of the saloon *Joseph Bosschieter (1885), Jennie's brother who was born in the Netherlands *Susan Bosschieter (1881), Jennie's sister who was born in the Netherlands
==Further reading== {{refbegin|2}} *[[New York Times]]; January 9, 1901. Within an Hour Jury Is Selected to Try the First Case. McAlister, Campbell, and Death Listen Nonchalantly to Testimony of the Victim's Family and Witnesses of the Crime. Separate Trial for Kerr. McAllister's Plea for a Review Denied. The first case taken up by Judge Dixon in the Supreme Court today was the application of George J. Kerr for a separate trial on the indictment charging him with assaulting and murdering Jennie Bosschieter, and of Walter C. McAllister for removal of the indictment to the Supreme Court, to the end that it may be reviewed and quashed ... *[[New York Times]]; January 15, 1901. [[Paterson, New Jersey]]; January 14, 1901. The trial of three of the four men who are accused of the murder of Jennie Bosschteter was begun in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, in the old Court House, in Main Street, today. The three men – Walter McAlister, Andrew Campbell, and William Death – who are the persons most concerned in the progress and outcome of the ... *[[New York Times]]; January 20, 1901. [[Paterson, New Jersey]]; January 19, 1901. The verdict in the Bosschieter case was the principal topic of conversation here today. In every shop, in every public place, the fate of Walter J. McAlister, Andrew J. Campbell, and William A. Death was discussed. So far as could be judged from a general expression of opinion, the verdict pleased. *[[New York Times]]; April 22, 1907. Bosschieter Convict Seeks Pardon. *[[New York Times]]; May 30, 1908. Bosschieter Slayer Seeks Pardon. *{{cite news| date=October 26, 2008| title=Attacked by the Gang| publisher=[[New York Daily News]] | quote=On a mild October evening in 1900, a pretty teenager named Jennie Bosschieter walked to a drugstore from her home in Paterson, N.J., to fetch baby powder for an infant niece.| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2008/10/25/2008-10-25_attacked_by_the_gang.html?page=0| accessdate=2008-10-29}} {{refend}}
==External links== *{{Find a Grave|49957201}}
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Kunduz Airlift ("Airlift of Evil") |partof=the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)]] |image= Afghanistan-Kunduz.png |image_size= 250px |caption=Kunduz in northern Afghanistan |date=November 2001 |place= [[Kunduz]], Afghanistan |coordinates= |map_type= |latitude = |longitude = |map_label = |result=about 5,000 [[Taliban]], [[Al-Qaeda]], Pakistani [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] and military personnel evacuated by [[Pakistan Air Force]] to northern [[Pakistan]]{{cite book|last=Hersh|first=Seymour M.|title=Chain of Command|year=2005|publisher=Harper Collins|isbn=978-0141020884|page=132}} |combatant1= {{flag|Pakistan}}
{{flagicon|Afghanistan|Taliban}} [[Taliban]]
{{flagicon image|Flag of al-Qaeda.svg}} [[Al-Qaeda]] |combatant2= {{flagicon|Afghanistan|1992}} [[United Islamic Front for the Salvation of Afghanistan|United Front of Afghanistan]] (Northern Alliance)
{{flag|United States|1960}} |commander1= |commander2= |strength1= |strength2= |casualties1= |casualties2= |}} The '''Kunduz airlift''' refers to the [[Emergency evacuation|evacuation]] of thousands of top commanders and members of the [[Taliban]] and [[Al-Qaeda]], their [[Pakistan]]i advisers including Pakistani [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] agents and army personnel, and other [[Jihad]]i volunteers and sympathizers, from the city of [[Kunduz]], Afghanistan, in November 2001{{cite book|last=Karlekar|first=Hiranmay|title=Endgame in Afghanistan: For Whom the Dice Rolls|year=2012|publisher=Sage|isbn=978-8132109747|page=206}} just before [[Siege of Kunduz|its capture]] by U.S. and [[United Islamic Front for the Salvation of Afghanistan|United Front of Afghanistan]] (Northern Alliance) forces during the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]]. As described in several reports, the Taliban and Al-Qaeda combatants were safely evacuated from Kunduz and [[airlift]]ed by [[Pakistan Air Force]] cargo aircraft to [[Pakistan Air Force]] bases in [[Chitral]] and [[Gilgit]] in Pakistan-administered Kashmir's [[Northern Areas]].{{cite web |first=Seymour M. |last=Hersh |url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2002/01/28/020128fa_FACT |title=The Getaway |date=2002-01-28 |accessdate=2008-02-15 |work=[[The New Yorker]]}}{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Moran |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3340165 |title=The ‘airlift of evil’ |date=2001-11-29 |accessdate=2008-02-15 |publisher=[[msnbc.com]]}}{{cite web |last=[[Press Trust of India]] |url=http://www.expressindia.com/news/fullstory.php?newsid=6813 |title=India protests airlift of Pakistani fighters from Kunduz |date=2002-01-24 |accessdate=2011-11-05 |work=[[The Indian Express]]}}{{cite web |first=Romesh |last=Ratnescar |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2002/ALLPOLITICS/10/10/timep.afghanistan.year.later.tm/index.html |title=Afghanistan: One year on |date=2002-10-10 |accessdate=2011-11-05 |publisher=[[CNN]]}}{{cite web |first=Marcus |last=George |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1677157.stm |title=Kunduz celebrates end of siege |date=2001-11-26 |accessdate=2008-02-15 |publisher=[[BBC News]]}}{{cite book |title=Descent into Chaos: The United States and the Failure of Nation Building in Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Central Asia |last=Rashid |first=Ahmed |year=2008 |publisher=[[Viking Press]] |location=United States |isbn=978-0-670-01970-0}}{{cite web |last=[[History Commons]] |url=http://www.historycommons.org/context.jsp?item=a1101airlift#a1101airlift |title=Context of "November 14-25, 2001: US Secretly Authorizes Airlift of Pakistani and Taliban Fighters" |date=2001-11-25 |accessdate=2011-11-05 |publisher=[[History Commons]]}} According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', during the [[siege of Kunduz]], U.S. and Northern Alliance forces (led by [[Mohammad Daud Daud]] and [[Abdul Rashid Dostum]]) had declared that they would treat foreign fighters of the Taliban (including Pakistani military advisers as well as Pakistani and Arab volunteers) more severely than their Afghan counterparts. The Northern Alliance had earlier witnessed Pakistani and Arab involvement in several massacres perpetrated by the Taliban in Afghanistan. Pakistani leaders feared that revenge killings of Pakistanis in Kunduz could lead to unrest and instability in their country and therefore decided to evacuate their forces before the U.S. and Northern Alliance ground forces moved into Kunduz.{{cite web |author=Paul Richter and Peter G. Gosselin|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/nov/26/news/mn-8445/2|title=Hundreds of Marines Land Near Kandahar; Kunduz Falls|date=2001-11-26 |accessdate= |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}} ==Revelation== The revelation that the U.S. had acquiesced to the escape of potentially dangerous individuals including the top leadership of the Taliban and Al Qaeda was a controversial and politically contentious topic that sparked off a debate in the western media and elicited denials of knowledge of this event from top [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]] officials including [[Secretary of Defense]] [[Donald Rumsfeld]]. Although numerous articles mentioning such an ongoing airlift of Pakistani and other combatants from Kunduz appeared around that time in several international newspapers (such as the ''[[New York Times]]'', ''[[The Independent]]'' and ''[[The Guardian]]''), the first reference to the specific term ''Airlift of Evil'' appeared in a column on the website of the [[MSNBC]] news network. It is generally thought that the U.S. administration agreed to the airlift in an attempt to appease Pakistani President [[Pervez Musharraf]]. This Pakistani evacuation of fighters belonging to the Taliban, Al Qaeda and the ISI is also detailed in the [[BBC]] documentary ''Secret Pakistan: Double Cross and Backlash''.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b016ltpv |title=Secret Pakistan: Double Cross |date=2011-10-26 |accessdate=2011-11-05 |publisher=[[BBC News]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b016n0js |title=Secret Pakistan: Backlash |date=2011-11-02 |accessdate=2011-11-05 |publisher=[[BBC News]]}} More details of the event finally emerged in the 2008 book ''Descent into Chaos'' by the investigative journalist [[Ahmed Rashid]]:
One senior (U.S.) intelligence analyst told me, "The request was made by Musharraf to Bush, but Cheney took charge—a token of who was handling Musharraf at the time. The approval was not shared with anyone at State, including Colin Powell, until well after the event.Two planes were involved, which made several sorties a night over several nights. They took off from air bases in [[Chitral]] and [[Gilgit]] in Kashmir's [[Northern Areas]], and landed in Kunduz, where the evacuees were waiting on the tarmac. Certainly hundreds and perhaps as many as one thousand people escaped. Hundreds of [[Inter-Services Intelligence|ISI]] officers, [[Taliban]] commanders, and foot soldiers belonging to the [[Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan]] and [[Al Qaeda]] personnel boarded the planes. What was sold as a minor extraction turned into a major air bridge. The frustrated U.S. SOF who watched it from the surrounding high ground dubbed it "Operation Evil Airlift."
Another senior U.S. diplomat told me afterward, "Musharraf fooled us because after we gave approval, the ISI may have run a much bigger operation and got out more people. We just don't know. At the time nobody wanted to hurt Musharraf. The real question is why Musharraf did not get his men out before. In one of Hillary Clintons emails, discussing the senate report on the Tora Bora escape of Bin Laden, Sidney Blumenthal talks about the Kunduz airlift as being ordered by Cheney/Rumsfeld.{{cite web |last=[[Sidney Blumenthal]] |url=https://wikileaks.org/clinton-emails/emailid/7373 |title=U.S. Department of State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05766983: "MEMO ON NEW SENATE REPORT ON TORA BORA AND ITS SIGNIFICANCE. SID" |date=2009-11-28 | accessdate=2016-04-07 |publisher=[[WikiLeaks]]}}
Gary Berntsen, the head of the CIA armed operation in eastern Afghanistan, is a major source for the report. I am in contact with him and have heard his entire story at length, key parts of which are not in his book, "Jawbreaker," or in the Senate report. In particular, the story of the Kunduz airlift of the bulk of key AQ and Taliban leaders, at the request of Musharaff and per order Cheney/Rumsfeld, is absent.
== References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Al-Qaeda]] [[Category:Afghanistan–Pakistan relations]] [[Category:Pakistan–United States relations]] [[Category:Taliban activities]] [[Category:War in Afghanistan (2001–present)]] [[Category:2001 in Afghanistan]] [[Category:2001 in Pakistan]] [[Category:Evacuations]]

revision.comment: new key for [[Category:State agencies of Louisiana]]: "recovery" using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{citations needed|date=January 2013}} The '''Louisiana Recovery Authority''' ('''LRA''') is the governmental body created in the aftermath of hurricanes [[Hurricane Katrina|Katrina]] and [[Hurricane Rita|Rita]] by Governor [[Kathleen Blanco]] to plan for the recovery and rebuilding of [[Louisiana]]. Under the leadership of the founding executive director, [[Andy Kopplin]], the authority's mission was to plan for Louisiana's future, coordinate across jurisdictions, support community recovery and resurgence, and ensure integrity and effectiveness. By working in collaboration with local, state and federal agencies, the authority's goal is to also address short-term recovery needs while guiding the long-term planning process.
Hurricanes [[Hurricane Katrina|Katrina]] and [[Hurricane Rita|Rita]] devastated South Louisiana, destroying more than 200,000 homes and 18,000 businesses and causing about $25 billion in insured losses. The LRA leads one of the most extensive rebuilding efforts in the world. The LRA's decisions are made by a 33-member board of directors, led by its chairman, [[Xavier University of Louisiana]] President [[Norman Francis]], and its vice chairman, journalist and author [[Walter Isaacson]]. The authority is staffed by fewer than 30 state government employees.
The LRA also designs all policy and programs funded by, thus far, $10.4 billion in federal [[Community Development Block Grant]] (CDBG) congressionally approved funds. The LRA's largest program dedicated $7.5 billion to helping residents of Louisiana affected by Hurricane Katrina or Rita get back into their homes as quickly and fairly as possible. This groundbreaking program, called the Road Home, represents the largest single housing recovery program in U.S. history.
The program affords eligible homeowners up to $150,000 in compensation for their losses to get back into their homes. As of February 1, 2008 the final number of applications received was 185,106. Of those applications received 159,406 were deemed eligible.
==External links== *[http://lra.louisiana.gov Official site]
[[Category:State agencies of Louisiana|recovery]] [[Category:Hurricane Katrina disaster relief]] [[Category:Hurricane Rita]]
{{Tropical-cyclone-stub}}

{{Infobox film festival | name = | image = LOGOFTV.jpg | image_size = 220px | caption = | number = | founded = 1961 | awards = Golden Nymph Awards | location = Grimaldi Forum, Monte-Carlo, [[Monaco]] | website = {{URL|www.tvfestival.com}} |Founder=Prince Rainier III|Awards=Golden Nymph|Duration=5 days}} [[File:GoldenNymph.JPG|thumb|[[Golden Nymph Award]]|289x289px]] [[File:ClotureFTV.jpg|thumb|alt=Texte alternatif|Golden Nymph Awards Ceremony]] [[File:PhotocallFTV.JPG|thumb|Red Carpet]] The '''Festival de Télévision de Monte-Carlo''' is an international festival and competition focusing on productions for [[television]], founded 1961 and based in [[Monaco]]. ==History== By creating the Festival de Télévision de Monte-Carlo in 1961, Prince [[Rainier III of Monaco]], wished to "encourage a new art form, in the service of peace and understanding between men." Monaco's international status ideally suited the Prince's ambition: to recognize television as an exceptional means of bringing cultures together and enhancing their respective knowledge. This project immediately generated worldwide interest and over the years, many distinguished celebrities have sat on the successive juries, bringing international recognition to the best of television programming. However, The Monter-Carlo Television Festival is above all, since the 1980s, a very important opportunity for business, a huge international market."Télé-Babel", [[Jean-Pierre Thiollet]], ''[[Le Quotidien de Paris]]'', 12 February 1982. H.S.H. [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Prince Albert II of Monaco]] has been the Honorary President of the Festival since 1988. The best of worldwide television programming has been rewarded with [[Golden Nymph Award|Golden Nymph]] statuettes, copies of the "[[Salmacis]]" Nymph by the Monegasque sculptor [[François Joseph Bosio]] (1768–1845), the original of which is on show at the [[Louvre Museum]] in [[Paris]]. ==Official Competition== The [[Golden Nymph Award]]s – with a Golden Nymph or a selection of Special Prizes – the best TV programs and actors from all around the world. Throughout the Festival, international juries composed of distinguished industry professionals and talent participate in screenings of all programming in Competition. Each year, more than 30 countries are represented in the competition, with more than 60 programs selected for nomination. The Competition is open to all international networks, distributors and production companies. The Official Competition is separated 2 Categories : *'''Fiction''' *'''News''' Other prizes are also awarded during the Golden Nymph Awards Ceremony - The International TV Audience Awards reward shows that have achieved the highest viewing figures worldwide. - The competition is also the host of Special Prizes awarded in partnership with major global organizations such as the International Committee of the Red Cross, the [[Monaco Red Cross]], the AMADE, SIGNIS and the Special Prize Rainier III - presented by H.S.H. Prince Albert II of Monaco. The Festival de Télévision de Monte-Carlo closes with the glittering Golden Nymph Award Ceremony. == Awards == === Fiction ===
* Best TV Series - Comedy * Outstanding Actor in a TV Series - Comedy * Outstanding Actress in a TV Series - Comedy
* Best TV Series - Drama * Outstanding Actor in a TV Series - Drama * Outstanding Actress in a TV Series - Drama
* Best Long Fiction Program * Outstanding Actor in a Long Fiction Program * Outstanding Actress in a Long Fiction Program === News === * Best News Documentary * Best Current Affaires Documentary * Best 24-Hour news Program * Best TV News Item === International TV Audience Awards === * Drama TV Series * Comedy TV Series * Telenovelas / Soap Operas === Special Prizes === * [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Prince Rainier III]] Special Prize * The Press Prize of the [[International Committee of the Red Cross|ICRC]] * Prize of the [[Red Cross of Monaco|Monaco Red Cross]] * The AMADE Prize * The SIGNIS Prize: The Silver Dove * The URTI Prize ==See also== {{Portal|Television}} *[[List of television festivals]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website}} *[https://www.imdb.com/Sections/Awards/Monte-Carlo_TV_Festival IMDB Festival Page] – For Some Historical Awards Data [[Category:Television festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in Monaco]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1961]] [[Category:1961 establishments in Monaco]] [[Category:Monaco stubs]] {{Monaco-stub}} {{festival-stub}} {{award-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Tina Harmon |image = Tina harmon.jpg |image size = 150px |image_caption = |birth_name = Tina Marie Harmon |birth_date = June 9, 1969 |birth_place = [[Creston, Ohio]], [[United States]] |death_date = {{Death-date and age| October 29, 1981 |June 9, 1969}} |death_place = Creston, Ohio, United States |death_cause = Strangulation |nationality = [[Americans|American]] |citizenship = United States |occupation = Student |known_for = Murder victim }} '''Tina Marie Harmon''' (born June 9, 1969 – October 29, 1981)<ref name=Grave /> was a 12-year-old [[Americans|American]] girl who was abducted, raped, and murdered on October 29, 1981 after being dropped off in [[Lodi, Ohio]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.indeonline.com/x415853804/UNSOLVED-MURDER-Family-of-Tina-Harmon-abducted-and-killed-in-1981-wants-investigtors-to-reopen-the-case|title=Family of Tina Harmon, abducted and killed in 1981, wants police to reopen the case|last=Rink|first=Matthew|work=The Independent|access-date=July 27, 2017|language=en}}</ref> After the discovery of her body, she was later buried at the Maple Mound Cemetery.<ref name="Grave">{{cite web|last=Reynolds|first=Krystin|title=Tina Marie Harmon|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/7366324|publisher=Find A Grave.com|accessdate=May 31, 2012|year=2003}}</ref> One man was originally convicted of her murder on circumstantial evidence but was eventually released when the conviction was overturned. Harmon's murder was solved in 2010 when [[DNA]] from the individual who raped her was matched to [[Robert Anthony Buell]].<ref name=Case/><ref name=vid>{{cite web|last=Renner|first=James|title=The Final Word on the Tragic Death of Krista Harrison|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=elfIzMihEsU|accessdate=March 17, 2014|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref>
==Case history== [[File:Harmon fibers.jpg|thumb|left|The polyester fibers found on Tina Harmon's body which matched the fibers from the van which was used in the abduction of Krista Harrison]] Tina Harmon was reportedly last seen with a man in his twenties after she had been dropped off by her father's girlfriend in [[Lodi, Ohio]].<ref name=Ghosts /> Harmon's body was later found next to an oil well site in [[Navarre, Ohio]], five days after her abduction.<ref name=Ghosts /> Nutmeg-colored carpet fibers and dog hair were found on her clothing.<ref name=files>Monahan, Richard, dir. "Material Evidence." Forensic Files. TLC, TruTV. October 31, 2000. Television.</ref><ref name="elusive">{{cite news |last1=Trexler |first1=Phil |title=Closure as elusive as killer for family grieving daughter |url=https://www.ohio.com/akron/news/closure-as-elusive-as-killer-for-family-grieving-daughter |accessdate=September 11, 2018 |work=Akron Beacon Journal |date=November 26, 2008}}</ref>
In 1982, Ernest Holbrook, Jr. and Henry Ray Rucker were convicted of both the rape and murder of Harmon, but after complications with the witnesses testimonies, one of them recanted. Rucker was given a new trial and was released in 1983.<ref name=Ghosts>{{cite news|last=Renner|first=James|title=Ghosts Of Wayne County Doubts Haunt An Old Murder And The Execution That Followed|url=http://www.clevescene.com/cleveland/ghosts-of-wayne-county/Content?oid=1534518|accessdate=February 24, 2014|newspaper=Cleveland Scene|date=December 30, 2008}}</ref>
==Robert Anthony Buell== In 1984, [[Robert Anthony Buell]] was convicted of the 1982 murder of [[Murder of Krista Harrison|Krista Lea Harrison]].<ref name=files/> The dog hairs on Harmon's body were matched to the ones found on a dog buried in Buell's yard, once DNA testing became possible.<ref name=Ghosts /> Buell was later matched to Harmon's murder by comparing his DNA samples with the ones found on Harmon's clothing several years later.<ref name="Final Word">{{cite web|last=Renner|first=James|title=The Final Word on Krista Harrison|url=http://jamesrenner.wordpress.com/2011/10/07/the-final-word-on-krista-harrison/|publisher=WordPress.com|accessdate=May 29, 2012|date=October 7, 2011}}</ref>
The nutmeg-colored carpet fibers that were found on both bodies of Harmon and Harrison matched as well.<ref name=Case>{{cite web|last=Renner|first=James|title=Case Closed!|url=http://www.clevelandindependent.com/2010/03/26/case-closed-2/|publisher=IndeOnline.com|accessdate=May 31, 2012|date=March 26, 2010}}</ref> However, Buell was never tried for her murder because he was already on death row.<ref name=files/> In 2002, Buell was executed for the murder of Harrison at age 62.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robert Anthony Buell #801|url=http://www.clarkprosecutor.org/html/death/US/buell801.htm|publisher=ClarkProsecutor.org|accessdate=May 31, 2012}}</ref>
Former journalist for the ''Cleveland Scene'' James Renner wrote about similar characteristics of the murders of Harmon, Harrison and Smith to the 1989 [[murder of Amy Mihaljevic]], which is currently unsolved. Although Buell was incarcerated at the time of Mihaljevic's death, he stated Buell's nephew may be responsible and stated he could have been involved in the three preceding murders, if not been the sole perpetrator. in 2008, the evidence in Harmon's case was compared to that in the Mihaljevic case.<ref name="elusive" /> Ross was eliminated as the source of DNA from the Harmon case in 2010.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Renner |first1=James |title=Finding Amy's Killer: Tina Harmon documents reveal Amy Mihaljevic info |url=http://amymihaljevic.blogspot.com/2010/03/tina-harmon-documents-reveal-amy.html |website=Finding Amy's Killer |accessdate=September 11, 2018 |date=March 19, 2010}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] *[[Murder of Krista Harrison]] *[[Robert Anthony Buell]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *{{YouTube|elfIzMihEsU|Presentation by James Renner}} *{{Find a Grave|7366324|Tina Harmon}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Harmon, Tina}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:1981 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths by strangulation in the United States]] [[Category:Formerly missing people found dead]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]] [[Category:Kidnappings in the United States]] [[Category:Kidnapped American children]] [[Category:Murdered American children]] [[Category:Murder in Ohio]] [[Category:People murdered in Ohio]] [[Category:Rapes in the United States]] [[Category:Victims of serial killers]] [[Category:Female murder victims]] [[Category:October 1981 events]]

'''Narcissism in the workplace''' is a serious issue and may have a major detrimental impact on an entire organization. [[Narcissism|Narcissistic]] individuals in the [[workplace]] are more likely to engage in [[counterproductive work behavior]], especially when their [[self-esteem]] is threatened.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bushman | first1 = B. J. | last2 = Baumeister | first2 = R. F. | year = 1998 | title = Threatened egotism, narcissism, self-esteem, and direct and displaced aggression: Does self-love or self-hate lead to violence? | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 75 | issue = 1| pages = 219–229 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.75.1.219 | pmid=9686460}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Penney | first1 = L. M. | last2 = Spector | first2 = P. E. | year = 2002 | title = Narcissism and counterproductive work behavior: Do bigger egos mean bigger problems? | url = | journal = International Journal of Selection and Assessment | volume = 10 | issue = 1–2| pages = 126–134 | doi = 10.1111/1468-2389.00199 }}</ref> Narcissism is both a personality trait and a [[personality disorder]], generally assessed with the [[Narcissistic Personality Inventory]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Judge | first1 = T. A. | last2 = LePine | first2 = J. A. | last3 = Rich | first3 = B. L. | year = 2006 | title = Loving Yourself Abundantly: Relationship of the Narcissistic Personality to Self- and Other Perceptions of Workplace Deviance, Leadership, and Task and Contextual Performance | url = |journal=[[Journal of Applied Psychology]] | volume = 91 | issue = 4| pages = 762–776 | doi=10.1037/0021-9010.91.4.762 | pmid=16834504}}</ref>
[[Oliver James (psychologist)|Oliver James]] identifies narcissism as one of the [[dark triad]]ic personality traits in the workplace, with the others being [[psychopathy]] and [[Machiavellianism]].<ref>James O Office Politics: How to Thrive in a World of Lying, Backstabbing and Dirty Tricks (2013)</ref> These three traits have been found to correlate moderately to strongly with one another.<ref>Furnham et al. (2017)[https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/spc3.12018 The Dark Triad of Personality: A 10 Year Review]</ref> Dark triad traits also share strong negative correlations with [[Honesty-humility factor of the HEXACO model of personality|Honesty-Humility]] traits.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Kibeom|last2=Ashton|first2=Michael C.|date=2005-05|title=Psychopathy, Machiavellianism, and Narcissism in the Five-Factor Model and the HEXACO model of personality structure|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S019188690400296X|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=38|issue=7|pages=1571–1582|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2004.09.016|issn=0191-8869|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180505134954/https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S019188690400296X|archivedate=2018-05-05|df=}}</ref> Narcissism is distinguished from the other dark triad traits by its positive correlations with openness and extroversion.
==Job interviews== {{Main|Job interviews}} Narcissists typically perform well at job interviews; they receive more favorable hiring ratings from interviewers than individuals who are not narcissists.<ref name = "Grijalva & Harms, 2014."> Grijalva, E., & Harms, P. D. (2014). Narcissism: An integrative synthesis and dominance complementarity model. The Academy of Management Perspectives, 28(2), 108-127.</ref> Even more experienced and trained raters evaluate narcissists more favorably.<ref name = "Brunell et al., 2008.">Brunell et al., 2008 A.B. Brunell, W.A. Gentry, W.K. Campbell, B.J. Hoffman, K.W. Kuhnert, K.G. Demarree. Leader emergence: The case of the narcissistic leader. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 34 (2008), pp. 1663–1676. </ref><ref name = "Schnure, 2010.">Schnure, K. (2010). Narcissism 101. Industrial Engineer, 42(8), 34-39.</ref> This is perhaps because interviews are one of the few social situations where narcissistic behaviors, such as [[boasting]], actually create a positive impression; however, favorable impressions of narcissists are often short-lived.<ref name = "Paulhus, 1998.">Paulhus, D. L. (1998). Interpersonal and intrapsychic adaptiveness of trait self-enhancement: A mixed blessing. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 74, 1197-1208.</ref> Interviewers’ initial impressions of narcissistic applicants are formed primarily on the basis of highly visible cues, which makes them susceptible to biases.<ref name = "Back, Schmuckle, & Egloff, 2010.">Back, M.D., Schmukle, S.C., & Egloff, B. (2010). Why are narcissists so charming at first sight? Decoding the narcissism-popularity link at zero acquaintance. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 98, 132-145. </ref>
Narcissists are more skilled at displaying likable cues, which lead to more positive first impressions, regardless of their long-term likability or job performance. Upon first meeting narcissists, people often rate them as more agreeable, competent, open, entertaining, and well-adjusted. Narcissists also tend to be neater and flashier dressers, display friendlier facial expressions, and exhibit more self-assured body movements.<ref name="Berscheid & Reis, 1998">Berscheid, E., & Reis, H. T. (1998). Attraction and close relationships.</ref> Importantly, while narcissistic individuals may rate their own job performance more favorably, studies show that narcissism is not related to job performance.<ref name="Campbell, Hoffman, Campbell, & Marchisio, 2011">Campbell, W. K., Hoffman, B. J., Campbell, S. M., & Marchisio, G. (2011). Narcissism in organizational contexts. Human Resource Management Review, 21(4), 268-284.</ref> Thus, while narcissists may seem to perform better and even be rated as performing better in interviews, these more favorable interview ratings are not predictive of favorable [[job performance]], as narcissists do not actually perform better in their jobs than non-narcissists.
==Impact on stress, absenteeism and staff turnover== {{Main|Occupational stress|Absenteeism|Turnover (employment)}} There tends to be a higher level of stress with people who work with or interact with a narcissist. While there are a variety of reasons for this to be the case, an important one is the relationship between narcissism and aggression. Penney and Spector found narcissism to be positively related to counterproductive workplace behaviors, such as interpersonal aggression, sabotaging the work of others, finding excuses to waste other peoples' time and resources, and spreading rumors.<ref>Penney, L. M., & Spector, P. E. (2002, June). Narcissism and Counterproductive WorkBehavior: Do Bigger Egos Mean Bigger Problems? Retrieved February 24, 2018, from <nowiki>http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1468-2389.00199/epdf</nowiki></ref> These aggressive acts can raise the stress of other employees<ref>Colligan, T. W., & Higgins, E. M. (2006). Workplace Stress. ''Journal of Workplace Behavioral Health,'' ''21''(2), 89-97. doi:10.1300/j490v21n02_07</ref>, which in turn increases absenteeism and staff turnover.<ref>Thomas, David. Narcissism: Behind the Mask (2010)</ref>
==Narcissistic supply== {{Main |Narcissistic supply}} The narcissistic manager will have two main sources of narcissistic supply: inanimate ([[status symbol]]s like cars, gadgets or office views); and animate ([[flattery]] and [[attention]] from colleagues and subordinates).<ref>A. J. DuBrin, ''Narcissism in the Workplace'' (2012) p. 143</ref> Teammates may find everyday offers of [[Social support|support]] swiftly turn them into [[enabling]] sources of permanent supply, unless they are very careful to maintain proper [[personal boundaries|boundaries]].<ref>A. J. DuBrin, ''Narcissism in the Workplace'' (2012) p. 143 and p. 181</ref> The narcissistic manager's need to protect such supply networks will prevent objective decision-making.<ref>S. Allcorn, ''Organizational Dynamics and Intervention'' (2005) p. 105</ref> Such a manager will evaluate long-term strategies according to their potential for gaining personal attention instead of to benefit the organization.<ref>A. J. DuBrin, ''Narcissism in the Workplace'' (2012) p. 122</ref>
==Preference for hierarchical organisations == Narcissists like [[hierarchical organisation]]s because they think they will rise to high ranks and reap status and [[Power (social and political)|power]]. They take special interest in acquiring leadership positions and may be better at procuring them<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Braun|first=Susanne|date=2017|title=Leader Narcissism and Outcomes in Organizations: A Review at Multiple Levels of Analysis and Implications for Future Research|url=http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fpsyg.2017.00773/full|journal=Frontiers in Psychology|language=English|volume=8|doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2017.00773|issn=1664-1078}}</ref>. Narcissists are less interested in hierarchies where there is little opportunity for upward mobility.<ref>Zitek E, Jordan A [https://hbr.org/2016/07/research-narcissists-dont-like-flat-organizations Research: Narcissists Don’t Like Flat Organizations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170107075648/https://hbr.org/2016/07/research-narcissists-dont-like-flat-organizations |date=2017-01-07 }} [[Harvard Business Review]] 27 Jul 2016</ref> A classic narcissist is more concerned with getting praised and how they are perceived than doing what benefits all of the "stakeholders". <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/sideways-view/201601/narcissism-work-the-arrogant-executive|title=Narcissism at Work: The Arrogant Executive|website=Psychology Today|language=en|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref> Some narcissistic attributes may confer benefits, but the negative and positive outcomes of narcissistic leadership are not yet fully understood.
==Corporate narcissism== {{See also|Organizational culture|}} According to Alan Downs, corporate narcissism occurs when a narcissist becomes the [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) (or another [[leadership]] role) within the [[senior management]] team and gathers an adequate mix of [[codependents]] around him or her to support the narcissistic behavior. Narcissists profess company [[loyalty]] but are only really committed to their own agendas; thus, organizational decisions are founded on the narcissist's own interests rather than the interests of the organization as a whole, the various stakeholders, or the society in which the organization operates.<ref name=downs>Downs, Alan: Beyond The Looking Glass: Overcoming the Seductive Culture of Corporate Narcissism, 1997</ref> As a result, a certain kind of charismatic leader can run a financially successful company on thoroughly unhealthy principles (at least for a time).<ref>Robin Skynner/John Cleese, ''Life and how to survive it'' (London 1994) p. 101</ref>
[[Neville Symington]] has suggested that one of the ways of differentiating a good-enough organisation from one that is pathological is through its ability to exclude narcissistic characters from key posts.<ref>[[Neville Symington]], ''Narcissism: A New Theory'' (London 2004) p. 10</ref>
==Coping strategies for dealing with workplace narcissists== DuBrin suggests the following coping strategies:<ref>A. J. DuBrin, ''Narcissism in the Workplace: Research, Opinion and Practice'' (2012)) p. 197</ref> * Assess the relationship realistically * Maintain your professionalism * [[flattery|Flatter]] the narcissistic manager * Confront the problem gently and tactfully * Document your accomplishments * Be willing to accept criticism * Over respond to the manager's pet peeves * Maintain a strong network
Another method for dealing with narcissism is the gray rock method<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://180rule.com/the-gray-rock-method-of-dealing-with-psychopaths/|title=The Gray Rock Method of Dealing With Psychopaths {{!}} 180 RULE|date=2012-03-30|work=180 RULE|access-date=2018-05-04|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220124231/http://180rule.com/the-gray-rock-method-of-dealing-with-psychopaths/|archivedate=2017-12-20|df=}}</ref>. This practice includes responding to the narcissist in monotone, emotionally void speaking patterns; avoiding addressing either party's personal life; and not engaging in stories or information designed to draw attention. For greatest effect, the user of the gray rock technique cannot allow the narcissist to know that it is in use. If they become aware of being manipulated, particularly volatile individuals may react explosively to try to get the user of the technique to break.
==Workplace bullying overlap== {{Main|Workplace bullying}} In 2007, researchers Catherine Mattice and Brian Spitzberg at [[San Diego State University]], USA, found that narcissism revealed a positive relationship with bullying. Narcissists were found to prefer indirect bullying tactics (such as withholding information that affects others' [[Job performance|performance]], ignoring others, spreading [[gossip]], constantly reminding others of mistakes, ordering others to do work below their competence level, and excessively monitoring others' work) rather than direct tactics (such as making threats, shouting, persistently criticizing, or making [[false allegations]]). Studies of adolescents using self-reports and teacher evaluation also indicated that narcissists are more likely to integrate aggressive and confrontational behaviors due to low self-esteem<ref>Washburn et al. 2004[https://dx.doi.org/10.1023/B:JOYO.0000025323.94929.d9 Narcissistic Features in Young Adolescents: Relations to Aggression and Internalizing Symptoms ]</ref><ref>Kerig & Stellwagen, 2010[https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10862-009-9168-7 Roles of callous-unemotional traits, narcissism, and machiavellianism in childhood aggression]</ref>.
The research also revealed that narcissists are highly motivated to bully, and that to some extent, they are left with feelings of satisfaction after a bullying incident occurs.<ref>Catherine Mattice, MA & Brian Spitzberg, PhD [http://noworkplacebullies.com/yahoo_site_admin/assets/docs/Bully_conference_abstract.160111428.doc Bullies in Business: Self-Reports of Tactics and Motives] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425093442/http://noworkplacebullies.com/yahoo_site_admin/assets/docs/Bully_conference_abstract.160111428.doc |date=2012-04-25 }} San Diego State University, 2007</ref> Despite the fact that many narcissist will avoid work, they can be eager to steal the work of others. In-line with other dark triad traits, many narcissists will manipulate others and their environment so that they can claim responsibility for company accomplishments that they had little or nothing to do with<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/communication-success/201504/10-signs-your-co-worker-colleague-is-narcissist|title=10 Signs Your Co-Worker / Colleague is a Narcissist|website=Psychology Today|language=en|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>.
==Sexual Harassment== Strong links between narcissism and sexual harassment, associated with ego centrism and willingness to exploit others<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jones|first=Daniel|last2=Paulhus|first2=Delroy|date=2011-10-01|title=The role of impulsivity in the Dark Triad of personality|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/251531395_The_role_of_impulsivity_in_the_Dark_Triad_of_personality|journal=Personality and Individual Differences - PERS INDIV DIFFER|volume=51|pages=679–682|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.04.011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180429155420/https://www.researchgate.net/publication/251531395_The_role_of_impulsivity_in_the_Dark_Triad_of_personality|archivedate=2018-04-29|df=}}</ref>. Additional research has also been done that directly correlates narcissism with a proclivity to engage in sexual harassment<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Kibeom|last2=Gizzarone|first2=Marie|last3=Ashton|first3=Michael C.|date=2003-07-01|title=Personality and the Likelihood to Sexually Harass|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1023961603479|journal=Sex Roles|language=en|volume=49|issue=1-2|pages=59–69|doi=10.1023/A:1023961603479|issn=0360-0025}}</ref>. Relevant correlates include sociosexuality, unrestricted sexuality, and extroversion.
==Productive narcissists== Crompton has distinguished what he calls ''productive narcissists'' from ''unproductive narcissists''.<ref>Simon Crompton, ''All about me'' (London 2007) pp. 157–58</ref> [[Michael Maccoby|Maccoby]] acknowledged that productive narcissists still tend to be over-sensitive to criticism, over-competitive, isolated, and grandiose, but considered that what draws them out is that they have a sense of freedom to do whatever they want rather than feeling constantly constrained by circumstances, and that through their charisma they are able to draw people into their vision, and produce a cohort of disciples who will pursue the dream for all it's worth.<ref>Maccoby M The Productive Narcissist (2003)</ref><ref>Crompton, p. 158</ref>
Others have questioned the concept, considering that the dramatic collapse of Wall Street and the financial system in 2009 must give us pause. Is the collapse due to business leaders who have developed narcissistic styles—even if ostensibly productive?<ref>Jay R. Slosar, ''The Culture of Excess'' (2009) p. 7</ref> Certainly one may conclude that at best there can be quite a fine line between narcissists who perform badly in the workplace because of their traits, and those who achieve outrageous success because of them.<ref>Crompton, p. 159</ref>
==In fiction== * [[Sheldon Cooper]] * [[Curb Your Enthusiasm#Characters|Larry David]] * [[Gordon Gekko]] * [[Gregory House]]

==Further reading== * Gerald Falkowski, Jean Ritala ''Narcissism in the Workplace'' (2007) * Samuel Grier ''Narcissism in the Workplace: What It Is - How To Spot It - What To Do About It'' (2011) * Belinda McDaniel ''The Narcissists in Your Life: Coping with and Surviving Narcissists in the Workplace, at Home and Wherever You Are Forced to Associate with People Suffering from Narcissistic Personality Disorder'' (2014) * [[Sam Vaknin]], Lidija Rangelovska ''The Narcissist and the Psychopath in the Workplace'' (2006)

{{Infobox NRHP | name =Nevada Theatre | image = Nevada_Theater-4.jpg | caption = | location= 401 Broad Street,
[[Nevada City, California]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|15|47|N|121|1|9|W|display=inline,title}} |locmapin = California#USA | built =1865 | added = March 14, 1973{{NRISref|2008a}} | designated_other1 = California | designated_other1_date = | designated_other1_number = 863 | governing_body = The Nevada Theatre Commission | refnum=73000417[http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/CA/Nevada/state.html National Register of Historical Places - CALIFORNIA (CA), Nevada County] }} The '''Nevada Theatre''', also known as the '''Cedar Theatre''', located in downtown [[Nevada City, California]], is California's oldest existing theater building.{{cite web |url=http://www.sierracinemas.com/nevada.html |title=Nevada Theatre Showtimes |accessdate=2008-07-21 |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |work= |publisher=sierracinemas.com}} Its principal periods of significance were 1850–1874, 1875–1899, 1900–1924, and 1925–1949. ==History== After the three-story Bailey House Hotel, at Broad and Bridge Streets, burned down in 1863, the Nevada Theatre Association began fundraising for a new building. Stock was sold at $100 a share, and a ball was held June 1865 to cover the remaining costs for the rustic vernacular [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] building.{{cite web |url=http://www.malakoff.com/nevadant.htm |title=The Nevada Theatre |accessdate=2008-07-22 |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |work= |publisher=malakoff.com}} The building's architect, builder, and engineer are unknown. When the theater opened on September 9, 1865,{{cite ohp|863|Nevada Theatre|2012-10-10}} the first performance was the [[John Poole (disambiguation)|John Poole]] two-act comedy entitled ''The Dutch Governor, or 'Twould Puzzle a Conjurer''. Silent films were screened as early as 1908, and the theater underwent a remodel in 1909, retrofitted as a movie house. A slanted floor and electric lights were added in 1915. By 1957, it closed because of a sluggish economy, but it was later purchased through public donations and reopened in 1968. ==Building== With over 200 seats, including balcony seating, the theater is in use year round for both live performance and movies. It is wheelchair accessible. The backstage area is located under the stage and is painted baby blue. It includes a small room with makeup mirrors.{{cite news |first=Keith |last=Sheffield |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Local theater profile: the Nevada Theatre and the Foothill Theatre Company |url=http://www.tahoe-world.com/content/view/8871/62/ |work= |publisher=tahoe-world.com |date=2007-04-09 |accessdate=2008-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703235036/http://www.tahoe-world.com/content/view/8871/62/ |archivedate=2008-07-03 |df= }} ==Performers== Notable past performers include [[Lotta Crabtree]], [[Mötley Crüe]], [[Jack London]], [[Emma Nevada]], [[Mark Twain]], and [[The Second City]] comedy troupe.{{cite web |url=http://www.nevadatheatre.com/ |title=Nevada Theater |accessdate=2008-07-21 |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |work= |publisher=nevadatheatre.com}} Present day main users include: * LeGacy Productionshttp://www.legacypresents.com/ * Nevada Theatre Film Series[http://www.sierracinemas.com/nevada.html Nevada Theatre Film Series] * Sierra Stages[http://www.sierrastages.org Sierra Stages] * Community Asian Theatre of the Sierrahttp://www.catsweb.org/ * Wild & Scenic Environmental Film Festivalhttp://www.wildandscenicfilmfestival.org/ Wild & Scenic Environmental Film Festival ==Commissions== The Nevada County Liberal Arts Commission was formed in the 1960s to purchase the building from [[United Artists]]. The Nevada Theatre Commission, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation, followed the first commission and, with a Board of Directors, is the governing body of the Nevada Theatre. It owns, operates, restores, and utilizes the theater "To preserve and develop the historic Nevada Theatre and its other historic properties in order to provide the community with an accessible, usable and valuable cultural asset" (Mission Statement). ==Landmark== The theater is registered as [[List of California Historical Landmarks#Nevada County|California Historical Landmark No. 863]], and was listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on March 14, 1973. The landmark plaque reads:
CALIFORNIA'S OLDEST EXISTING THEATRE BUILDING, THE NEVADA OPENED SEPTEMBER 9, 1865. CELEBRITIES SUCH AS MARK TWAIN, JACK LONDON, AND EMMA NEVADA HAVE APPEARED ON ITS STAGE. CLOSED IN 1957, THE THEATRE WAS LATER PURCHASED THROUGH PUBLIC DONATIONS AND REOPENED MAY 7, 1968 TO AGAIN SERVE THE CULTURAL NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY.
CALIFORNIA REGISTERED HISTORICAL LANDMARK NO. 863
PLAQUE PLACED BY THE STATE DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION IN COOPERATION WITH THE HISTORICAL LANDMARKS AND LIBERAL ARTS COMMISSIONS OF NEVADA COUNTY, APRIL 27, 1974.
